title: Ansible Basics
description: Learn Ansible automation fundamentals including playbooks, roles, inventory, modules, variables, and configuration management best practices.

cards.back: Ansible is an agentless automation tool for configuration management, application deployment, and orchestration. Uses SSH for Linux/Unix and WinRM for Windows. Written in Python, uses YAML for playbooks. No agents needed on managed nodes.

A Playbook is a YAML file defining automation tasks. Contains plays (groups of tasks) targeting hosts. Playbooks are idempotent (safe to run multiple times), declarative (describe desired state), and reusable.

Inventory lists managed hosts/groups. Format: INI or YAML. Can be static (file) or dynamic (script/plugin generating from cloud APIs). Define variables per host/group. Default: /etc/ansible/hosts. Example groups: [webservers], [databases].

Modules are reusable units executing specific tasks (install package, copy file, manage service). Examples: apt, yum, copy, file, service, user, git, docker_container. Over 3000+ built-in modules. Write custom modules in any language.

Roles organize playbooks into reusable, structured components. Standard directory structure: tasks/, handlers/, templates/, files/, vars/, defaults/, meta/. Share via Ansible Galaxy. Roles promote modularity and reusability.

Tasks are individual actions executed by modules. Each task has name, module, and parameters. Run sequentially. Support conditionals (when:), loops (loop:), error handling (ignore_errors, failed_when), and delegation (delegate_to:).

Handlers are special tasks triggered by notify directive. Run once at play end, even if notified multiple times. Used for service restarts after config changes. Example: notify: restart nginx triggers handler to restart service only if config changed.

Variables store values for reuse in playbooks. Define in playbooks, inventory, roles, command-line (--extra-vars). Access with {{ var_name }}. Precedence order: extra-vars (highest), task vars, role vars, inventory vars, role defaults (lowest).

Facts are system information automatically gathered from managed hosts (OS, IP, memory, disks). Accessed via ansible_facts dictionary. Example: {{ ansible_facts.hostname }}. Gather with setup module. Disable with gather_facts: false for speed.

Templates use Jinja2 syntax to generate dynamic files. Variables, conditionals, loops in .j2 files. Module template copies rendered file to hosts. Example: Deploy config files with environment-specific values. Common for nginx.conf, application.properties.

Idempotence means running playbook multiple times produces same result without unwanted changes. Ansible modules are idempotent by design. Example: package installation checks if already installed. Ensures safe reruns and prevents configuration drift.

Ansible Vault encrypts sensitive data (passwords, keys) in playbooks/variables. Commands: ansible-vault create, encrypt, decrypt, edit. Use --ask-vault-pass or --vault-password-file when running. Encrypted files are safe to commit to Git.

Ansible Galaxy is a repository for sharing Ansible roles and collections. Install roles: ansible-galaxy install username.rolename. Collections bundle modules, plugins, roles. Public hub at galaxy.ansible.com. Create requirements.yml for dependencies.

Use roles for organization, name all tasks clearly, use variables for flexibility, encrypt secrets with Vault, use version control, test with --check mode, keep playbooks idempotent, document with comments, use tags for selective execution, follow directory structure conventions.
